narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Interesting topics discussed in class. This class provides a lot of context to global issues and strategies aiming to help improve learning among individuals all over the world. So many great speakers that made the class so much fun!
Knowledge related to reading in the brain and global literacy

I learned a lot about how the brain reads and the different tracks it can take. We also had a number of guest speakers that gave insight into what brain research and literacy activism can look like outside the academic setting.
Greater critical thinking skills and insight into the complex interactions between society and neuroscience.

By taking this course, I developed research skills such as applying research methods to neurological research and how to bridge the gap between research and application. I learned how to efficiently read technical papers and write concisely in summary.
I learned about the neuroscience of literacy and how to extract the main ideas from technical research articles.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was not at all how it was described on Canvas. I hesitate to consider this class a social science. The entire semester was dedicated to the brain and not enough to social policy or practical application. While the guest speakers were great and Prof. Pugh is extremely passionate and knowledgeable on the subject of language and the brain, this course was not well organized and incredibly un-engaging. To be fair, this is the first time this course was taught, but I felt it needed a lot more structure and development before being taught. There wasn't even a syllabus, the assignments were open-ended, unclear and not challenging, and there often was no concrete due date, which is confusing and stressful. Hopefully in the future this course will be more structured and better developed.

This course provided a lot of context and updates on current research! This is amazing. Many classes will teach you about a topic but never put you in conversation with the current studies, and this course did! This course brought in people currently and actively working in the things we discussed in lecture.

Strengths: Guest speakers, interesting papers, not too much reading, professor that's passionate about the subject

Weaknesses: Spent much longer on the nueroscience side of things than I expected, Professor went off on tangents a lot (related information, but off course a bit)
Amazing guest speakers and knowledgeable professor

Prof. Pugh is wonderful, and the involvement of outside speakers really added a lot to class discourse and our understanding of the field and its real-world implications. I do, however, think there would be benefit to having a more solid syllabus outline from the start to give students an idea of the trajectory the class will take, even if it's just a schedule of what topics will be covered.

The biggest weakness was that we were never given a syllabus and homework/papers would be handed to us randomly with no consistency. One of the strengths was the fact that Professor P brought a lot of speakers and we were  able to get a big scope of global literacy from all angles.

Strength - guest lectures allowed for students to interact with professionals in field
Weakness - more focus on neuroscience and less focus on policy compared to what was outlined in syllabus, organization

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. I think it would be best suited for someone that wants to combine the worlds of nueroscience and education studies. While some of the information was harder science (tools used for different brain scans), most of it was easily understood by me, someone without any technical skills. I also have no background in nueroscience, so I'd say it was a good introduction to some of the topics you'd see following along that major.
I would not. The professor is so nice but the course was very disorganized and I did not feel like I was learning all of the time.
Yes, if the student is interested in the neuroscience of literacy this class is a great fit
